title: How to Minimise AI Hallucinations in Research and Writing
subtitle: An exercise for anyone who wants accuracy rather than anxiety.
author: Dr Sam Illingworth
content_html:
Most debates about AI hallucination fall into two simple stories. Some blame the user, while others blame the system. Somewhere in the middle sit the people actually trying to work with these tools in research, writing, and daily decision making. Risks are real, but fear provides no safety.

In this post we will:

  • Offer a way to separate user risk from ecosystem risk.

  • Work with one prompt that sharpens your awareness of context.

  • Open a discussion about how to use AI well without surrendering critical thinking.

If you clear away the noise, a practical question appears. Where does the danger really come from? System errors often stem from poor context or a polluted information environment. Distinguishing between these causes is more critical than slogans regarding trust.

This week’s Slow AI prompt comes from at AI Proem and Proem Communications. It’s a small experiment in seeing how a tool can help you think clearly about accuracy, risk, and your own responsibility as a researcher.

AI fails in two different ways, and we often fail with it. The first is error. The second is intent. Treating these as the same problem leads to weak choices.

On the error side, chatbots misfire because the context is thin or the task is vague. The model guesses, fills gaps, and produces confident nonsense. Clear prompts reduce errors without eliminating them entirely.

The other category is deliberate misuse. Voice and video fabrications are already used for fraud, coercion and misinformation. This represents deliberate human choice facilitated by technology.

Slow AI begins by naming these failures plainly so we can respond with more care and less panic.

Slow AI is a shared space for reflection. Posts are free. Paid subscriptions support the work.

Step by step

Try this prompt with your AI tool of choice:

You are a researcher learning learning how to minimise hallucinations when using AI for research or writing on [insert topic]. Explain the difference between gaps caused by missing context and errors caused by poisoned information in the wider web. Map out where my decisions matter most as a writer and researcher. Give specific examples of what good context looks like and what the boundaries of your knowledge as an AI tool actually are.

Before you start, set clear limits for the exchange. Treat every factual claim as provisional until you verify it yourself. Keep personal details out of the discussion. Keep sensitive material out as well. This secures your privacy and work credibility.

Use the prompt for a topic that genuinely matters. A dataset you cannot reconcile. A brief that has gaps. A theory you only partly understand. Pay attention to how it describes its own blind spots. Then notice which parts of that account help you judge the safety of the output that follows.

A moment from

I started with a very generic prompt about chatbots, asking ChatGPT to explain the risks of companion-style chatbots and to tell me where it might go wrong in my own research. From that, it generated a long, comprehensive report: it mapped out the main players in the space, the different use cases for companion bots, the risks of blurring reality, the potential benefits for loneliness, the underlying tech stack, early regulation, and the pace of diffusion.

Then I narrowed the brief. I told the chatbot to focus on a specific vertical of companion bots: those used for dating or romance, and to limit the analysis to the U.S. market. That extra context and specificity immediately sharpened the output. It understood the scope of my research much better and stopped wasting space on regions or use cases I didn’t care about.

Crucially, I also asked it to flag places where it might be wrong. The tool provided source links and highlighted high-risk areas for investigation.

The final result was a report broken into clear topical sections that mirrored the way I’d framed my prompts. It followed a logical, easy-to-read flow and surfaced concrete data points I could then fact-check. By the time I got to my ‘human pass’, the output required only the final 20% of effort, specifically verification and editing.

Nominate a Substack writer for a boost via the Slow AI Supporters Programme. I will then share their work in a Note to build our community.

What to do with it

If you want to share:

  • Explain one insight the prompt gave you about user error.

  • Identify one moment where the system hallucinated and describe how you caught it.

  • Note how attention changed when the focus moved from generic cautions to observing personal checking habits.

The aim is steady, calm attention while working beside a tool that is already woven into daily life.

Why this matters

AI will continue to advance, but the real choice lies in how people meet it. A slower and more deliberate approach helps. This approach requires personal guardrails, human verification, and viewing AI as a fallible tool. Early internet services bore little resemblance to what followed, and AI will also shift in unpredictable ways. Any sensible practice needs room for that change.

The wider pressures must stay in view. Data centres require land and electricity, attention is stretched across too many tasks, and psychological and physical boundaries are tested. Progress is neither neutral nor inevitable.

The risks come from the technology’s own limits and from people who deliberately pollute the information environment. You control your response despite uncontrollable external risks.

Understanding how hallucination happens makes careful prompting easier.

Understanding how misinformation spreads strengthens your audit.

You hold on to your own thinking and remain responsible for what you publish. In that spirit, Slow AI becomes a practice of verification, clarity, and mindful adoption as the technology moves into hardware, wearables, social platforms, medicine, and education.

From Is Your Chatbot a Pipeline to Extremism?

and I were struck by how much of the conversation focused on drift rather than intent. Readers saw persuasion not as a sudden event, but as a gradual pull that relies on repetition, trust, and emotional availability.

sharpened this from the outset. Her point about persuasion without noise highlighted how influence works through accumulation. The risk is not in dramatic statements, but in countless minor nudges that feel too small to matter until they do.

pushed that line further by naming the role of confidence and authority. When a system sounds sure, people who lack AI literacy tend to believe it. That creates a tension between ease of use and depth of understanding. Trust fills the gap, and trust is where thinking can begin to drift.

widened the frame by linking the technology to context. His focus on young men seeking somewhere to vent showed why the mechanism is not just informational. It is relational. The danger is movement over months, shaped by loneliness, certainty, and design.

Taken together, these reflections point to a shared concern. Influence is most dangerous when it feels benign. Slow AI creates the pause needed to notice direction before direction becomes momentum.
